render.tex: \textcolor{blue}{\text{Adjoint of a Matrix}} \\ %text How to determine the Adjoint of a Matrix %

reason.tex:
%text A is a $3\times 3$ matrix we will use as an example to understand how to find Adjoint of a matrix % \begin{align} A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc} a_1 & a_2 & a_3 \\ b_1 & b_2 & b_3 \\ c_1 & c_2 & c_3 \end{array}\right] \end{align} \\ %text Start by constructing the cofactor matrix. Each element in the cofactor matrix is the Determinant remaining when the row and column containing that element are removed from the original matrix, multiplied by $(-1)^\text{row+col}$ % \begin{align} CF(a_1)&=(b_2c_3-c_2b_3)(-1)^{(1+1)} \\ CF(b_1)&=(a_2c_3-c_2a_3)(-1)^{(2+1)} \\ CF(c_1)&=(a_2b_3-b_2a_3)(-1)^{(3+1)} \\ ...& \\ CF(c_3)&=(a_1b_2-b_1a_2)(-1)^{(3+3)} \\ \end{align} \\
%text The final cofactor matrix looks like this, % \begin{align} CF&=\left[\begin{array}{ccc} b_2c_3-c_2b_3 & c_1b_3-b_1c_3 & b_1c_2-c_1b_2 \\ c_2a_3-a_2c_3 & a_1c_3-c_1a_3 & c_1a_2-a_1c_2 \\ a_2b_3-b_2a_3 & b_1a_3-a_1b_3 & a_1b_2-b_1a_2 \end{array}\right] \end{align} \\
%text All we need to do now is a transpose - rows to columns, columns to rows, and we have the Adjoint, %
\begin{align} Adj(A)&=\left[\begin{array}{ccc} b_2c_3-c_2b_3 & c_2a_3-a_2c_3 & a_2b_3-b_2a_3 \\ c_1b_3-b_1c_3 & a_1c_3-c_1a_3 & b_1a_3-a_1b_3 \\ b_1c_2-c_1b_2 & c_1a_2-a_1c_2 & a_1b_2-b_1a_2 \end{array}\right] \end{align} \\
%text For a $2\times 2$ matrix, it is even simpler, %
\begin{align} B=\left[\begin{array}{cc} a_1 & a_2 \\ b_1 & b_2 \end{array}\right] \implies Adj(B)=\left[\begin{array}{cc} b_2 & -a_2 \\ -b_1 & a_1 \end{array}\right] \end{align}
